text: #grapple (third-person singular simple present grapples, present participle grappling, simple past and past participle grappled)
(transitive) To seize something and hold it firmly.
(intransitive) To wrestle or tussle.

text.text: (figurative, with with) To ponder and intensely evaluate a problem.
examples: to grapple with one's conscience

text: #grapple (countable and uncountable, plural grapples)
A close hand-to-hand struggle; (uncountable) the act of grappling.
#grapple (plural grapples)
A tool with claws or hooks which is used to catch or hold something.
(nautical) A device consisting of iron claws, attached to the end of a rope, used for grasping and holding an enemy ship prior to boarding; a grappling iron.
(nautical) A grapnel (“type of anchor”).
#grapple (third-person singular simple present grapples, present participle grappling, simple past and past participle grappled)
(transitive) To fasten, as with a grapple; (by extension) to fix; to join indissolubly.
(transitive, intransitive) To climb (whether by means of a grapple and rope, or by hand, etc).
(intransitive) To use a grapple (for example to attempt to find, hook, and raise a net or cable).
(transitive, intransitive) To hook and raise with a grapple.
#cat (plural cats)
An animal of the family Felidae:
A domesticated subspecies (Felis silvestris catus) of feline animal, commonly kept as a house pet. [from 8thc.]
Any similar animal of the family Felidae, which includes lions, tigers, bobcats, etc.
A person:
(offensive) A spiteful or angry woman. [from early 13thc.]
An enthusiast or player of jazz.
(slang) A person (usually male).
(slang) A prostitute. [from at least early 15thc.]
(nautical) A strong tackle used to hoist an anchor to the cathead of a ship.
(chiefly nautical) Short form of cat-o'-nine-tails.
(archaic) A sturdy merchant sailing vessel (now only in "catboat").
(archaic, uncountable) The game of "trap and ball" (also called "cat and dog").
The trap of the game of "trap and ball".
(archaic) The pointed piece of wood that is struck in the game of tipcat.
(slang, vulgar, African American Vernacular English) A vagina, a vulva; the female external genitalia.
A double tripod (for holding a plate, etc.) with six feet, of which three rest on the ground, in whatever position it is placed.
(historical) A wheeled shelter, used in the Middle Ages as a siege weapon to allow assailants to approach enemy defences.
#cat (third-person singular simple present cats, present participle catting, simple past and past participle catted)
(nautical, transitive) To hoist (the anchor) by its ring so that it hangs at the cathead.
(nautical, transitive) To flog with a cat-o'-nine-tails.
(slang) To vomit something.
To go wandering at night.
To gossip in a catty manner.
#cat (plural cats)
Abbreviation of catamaran.
#cat (plural cats)
(computing) A program and command in Unix that reads one or more files and directs their content to the standard output.
#cat (third-person singular simple present cats, present participle catting, simple past and past participle catted)
(computing, transitive) To apply the cat command to (one or more files).
(computing, slang) To dump large amounts of data on (an unprepared target) usually with no intention of browsing it carefully.
#cat (not comparable)

text.text: (Ireland, informal) Terrible, disastrous.
examples: The weather was cat, so they returned home early.

text: #cat (uncountable)
(slang) A street name of the drug methcathinone.
#cat (plural cats)

text.text: (military, naval) A catapult.
examples: a carrier's bow cats

text: #cat (plural cats)
Abbreviation of category.
#cat (plural cats)
Abbreviation of catfish.
#cat (plural cats)
(slang) Any of a variety of earth-moving machines. (from their manufacturer Caterpillar Inc.)
A caterpillar drive vehicle (a ground vehicle which uses caterpillar tracks), especially tractors, trucks, minibuses, and snow groomers.
#dog (plural dogs)

text.text: A mammal, Canis lupus familiaris, that has been domesticated for thousands of years, of highly variable appearance due to human breeding.
examples: The dog barked all night long.

text: Any member of the Family Canidae, including domestic dogs, wolves, coyotes, jackals, foxes, and their relatives (extant and extinct); canid.
(often attributive) A male dog, wolf or fox, as opposed to a bitch or vixen.

text.text: (slang, derogatory) A dull, unattractive girl or woman.
examples: She’s a real dog.

text.text: (slang) A man (derived from definition 2).
examples: You lucky dog!
He's a silly dog.

text.text: (slang, derogatory) A coward.
examples: Come back and fight, you dogs!

text.text: (derogatory) Someone who is morally reprehensible.
examples: You dirty dog.

text: (slang) A sexually aggressive man (cf. horny).
Any of various mechanical devices for holding, gripping, or fastening something, particularly with a tooth-like projection.
(Can we clean up(+) this sense?) A click or pallet adapted to engage the teeth of a ratchet-wheel, to restrain the back action; a click or pawl. (See also: ratchet, windlass)

text.text: A metal support for logs in a fireplace.
examples: The dogs were too hot to touch.

text: (cartomancy) The eighteenth Lenormand card.
A hot dog.
(poker slang) Underdog.

text.text: (slang, almost always  in the plural) Foot.
examples: My dogs are barking! ― My feet hurt!

text.text: (Cockney rhyming slang) (from "dog and bone") Phone or mobile phone.
examples: My dog is dead.My mobile-phone battery has run out of charge and is no longer able to function.

text: One of the cones used to divide up a racetrack when training horses.
shortened form of dog meat.
(film, slang) A flop; a film that performs poorly at the box office.
#dog (third-person singular simple present dogs, present participle dogging, simple past and past participle dogged)
(transitive) To pursue with the intent to catch.

text.text: (transitive) To follow in an annoying or harassing way.
examples: The woman cursed him so that trouble would dog his every step.

text.text: (transitive, nautical) To fasten a hatch securely.
examples: It is very important to dog down these hatches...

text.text: (intransitive, emerging usage in  Britain) To watch, or participate, in sexual activity in a public place.
examples: I admit that I like to dog at my local country park.

text.text: (intransitive, transitive) To intentionally restrict one's productivity as employee; to work at the slowest rate that goes unpunished.
examples: A surprise inspection of the night shift found that some workers were dogging it.

text: (transitive) To criticize.
(transitive, military) To divide (a watch) with a comrade.
#test (plural tests)
A challenge, trial.
A cupel or cupelling hearth in which precious metals are melted for trial and refinement.
(academia) An examination, given often during the academic term.
A session in which a product or piece of equipment is examined under everyday or extreme conditions to evaluate its durability, etc.
(cricket, normally “Test”) A Test match.
(marine biology) The external calciferous shell, or endoskeleton, of an echinoderm, e.g. sand dollars and sea urchins.
(botany) Testa; seed coat.
(obsolete) Judgment; distinction; discrimination.
#test (third-person singular simple present tests, present participle testing, simple past and past participle tested)

text.text: To challenge.
examples: Climbing the mountain tested our stamina.

text: To refine (gold, silver, etc.) in a test or cupel; to subject to cupellation.

text.text: To put to the proof; to prove the truth, genuineness, or quality of by experiment, or by some principle or standard; to try.
examples: to test the soundness of a principle; to test the validity of an argument

text: (academics) To administer or assign an examination, often given during the academic term, to (somebody).
To place a product or piece of equipment under everyday and/or extreme conditions and examine it for its durability, etc.

text.text: (copulative) To be shown to be by test.
examples: He tested positive for cancer.

text.text: (chemistry) To examine or try, as by the use of some reagent.
examples: to test a solution by litmus paper

text: #test (plural tests)
(obsolete) A witness.
#test (third-person singular simple present tests, present participle testing, simple past and past participle tested)
(obsolete, transitive) To attest (a document) legally, and date it.
(obsolete, intransitive) To make a testament, or will.
#test (uncountable)
(informal, slang, body building) testosterone
#house (countable and uncountable, plural houses or (dialectal) housen or (chiefly humorous) hice)

text.text: A structure built or serving as an abode of human beings. [from 9th c.]
examples: This is my house and my family's ancestral home.

text: The people who live in a house; a household. [from 9th c.]

text.text: A building used for something other than a residence (typically with qualifying word). [from 10th c.]
examples: The former carriage house had been made over into a guest house.
On arriving at the zoo, we immediately headed for the monkey house.

text.text: A place of business; a company or organisation, especially a printing press, a publishing company, or a couturier. [from 10th c.]
examples: A small publishing house would have a contract with an independent fulfillment house.

text.text: A place of public accommodation or entertainment, especially a public house, an inn, a restaurant, a theatre, or a casino; or the management thereof.[from 10th c.]
examples: One more, sir, then I'll have to stop serving you – rules of the house, I'm afraid.
The house always wins.

text: (historical) A workhouse.
The audience for a live theatrical or similar performance. [from 10th c.]

text.text: A theatre.
examples: After her swan-song, there wasn't a dry eye in the house.

text.text: (politics) A building where a deliberative assembly meets; whence the assembly itself, particularly a component of a legislature. [from 10th c.]
examples: The petition was so ridiculous that the house rejected it after minimal debate.

text.text: A dynasty; a family with its ancestors and descendants, especially a royal or noble one. [from 10th c.]
examples: A curse lay upon the House of Atreus.

text: (figurative) A place of rest or repose. [from 9th c.]

text.text: A grouping of schoolchildren for the purposes of competition in sports and other activities. [from 19th c.]
examples: I was a member of Spenser house when I was at school.

text: An animal's shelter or den, or the shell of an animal such as a snail, used for protection. [from 10th c.]
(astrology) One of the twelve divisions of an astrological chart. [from 14th c.]
(cartomancy) The fourth Lenormand card.
(chess, now rare) A square on a chessboard, regarded as the proper place of a piece. [from 16th c.]
(curling) The four concentric circles where points are scored on the ice. [from 19th c.]
Lotto; bingo. [from 20th c.]

text.text: (uncountable) A children's game in which the players pretend to be members of a household.
examples: As the babysitter, Emma always acted as the mother whenever the kids demanded to play house.

text: (US, dialect) A small stand of trees in a swamp.
(sudoku) A set of cells in a Sudoku puzzle which must contain each digit exactly once, such as a row, column, or 3×3 box in classic Sudoku.
#house (third-person singular simple present houses, present participle housing, simple past and past participle housed)

text.text: (transitive) To keep within a structure or container.
examples: The car is housed in the garage.

text: (transitive) To admit to residence; to harbor/harbour.
To take shelter or lodging; to abide; to lodge.
(transitive, astrology) To dwell within one of the twelve astrological houses.
(transitive) To contain or cover mechanical parts.
(obsolete) To drive to a shelter.
(obsolete) To deposit and cover, as in the grave.

text.text: (nautical) To stow in a safe place; to take down and make safe.
examples: to house the upper spars

text: (Canada, US, slang, transitive) To eat.
#house (uncountable)
(music) House music.
#game (countable and uncountable, plural games)
A playful or competitive activity.

text.text: A playful activity that may be unstructured; an amusement or pastime.
examples: Being a child is all fun and games.

text.text: (countable) An activity described by a set of rules, especially for the purpose of entertainment, often competitive or having an explicit goal.
examples: Games in the classroom can make learning fun.

text.text: (countable) A particular instance of playing a game; match.
examples: Sally won the game.
They can turn the game around in the second half.

text: That which is gained, such as the stake in a game.

text.text: The number of points necessary to win a game.
examples: In short whist, five points are game.

text: (card games) In some games, a point awarded to the player whose cards add up to the largest sum.

text.text: (countable) The equipment that enables such activity, particularly as packaged under a title.
examples: Some of the games in the closet we have on the computer as well.

text.text: One's manner, style, or performance in playing a game.
examples: Study can help your game of chess.
Hit the gym if you want to toughen up your game.

text: (obsolete, uncountable) An amorous dalliance.
(countable) A video game.

text.text: (countable, informal, nearly always singular) A field of gainful activity, as an industry or profession.
examples: When it comes to making sales, John is the best in the game.
He's in the securities game somehow.

text.text: (countable, figurative) Something that resembles a game with rules, despite not being designed.
examples: In the game of life, you may find yourself playing the waiting game far too often.

text: (countable, military) An exercise simulating warfare, whether computerized or involving human participants.

text.text: (uncountable) Wild animals hunted for food.
examples: The forest has plenty of game.

text.text: (uncountable, informal, used mostly of males) The ability to seduce someone, usually by strategy.
examples: He didn't get anywhere with her because he had no game.

text: (uncountable, slang) Mastery; the ability to excel at something.

text.text: (countable) A questionable or unethical practice in pursuit of a goal; a scheme.
examples: You want to borrow my credit card for a week? What's your game?

text: #game (comparative gamer, superlative gamest)
(colloquial) Willing to participate.
(of an animal) That shows a tendency to continue to fight against another animal, despite being wounded, often severely.
Persistent, especially in senses similar to the above.
Injured, lame (of a limb).
#game (third-person singular simple present games, present participle gaming, simple past and past participle gamed)
(intransitive) To gamble.
(intransitive) To play video games.

text.text: (transitive) To exploit loopholes in a system or bureaucracy in a way which defeats or nullifies the spirit of the rules in effect, usually to obtain a result which otherwise would be unobtainable.
examples: We'll bury them in paperwork, and game the system.

text: (transitive, slang, of males) To perform premeditated seduction strategy.
#line (plural lines)

text.text: A path through two or more points (compare ‘segment’); a continuous mark, including as made by a pen; any path, curved or straight.
examples: The arrow descended in a curved line.

text: (geometry) An infinitely extending one-dimensional figure that has no curvature; one that has length but not breadth or thickness.
(geometry, informal) A line segment; a continuous finite segment of such a figure.
(graph theory) An edge of a graph.
(geography) A circle of latitude or of longitude, as represented on a map.
(geography, ‘the line’ or ‘equinoctial line’) The equator.
(music) One of the straight horizontal and parallel prolonged strokes on and between which the notes are placed.
(cricket) The horizontal path of a ball towards the batsman (see also length).
(soccer) The goal line.
A rope, cord, string, or thread, of any thickness.

text.text: A hose or pipe, of any size.
examples: a brake line
the main water line to the house

text.text: Direction, path.
examples: the line of sight
the line of vision

text.text: The wire connecting one telegraphic station with another, a telephone or internet cable between two points: a telephone or network connection.
examples: I tried to make a call, but the line was dead.
a dedicated line;  a shared line
Please speak up, the line is very faint.

text: A clothesline.

text.text: A letter, a written form of communication.
examples: Drop me a line.

text.text: A connected series of public conveyances, as a roadbed or railway track; and hence, an established arrangement for forwarding merchandise, etc.
examples: a line of stages
an express line

text: (military) A trench or rampart, or the non-physical demarcation of the extent of the territory occupied by specified forces.
The exterior limit of a figure or territory: a boundary, contour, or outline; a demarcation.
A long tape or ribbon marked with units for measuring; a tape measure.
(obsolete) A measuring line or cord.
That which was measured by a line, such as a field or any piece of land set apart; hence, allotted place of abode.
A threadlike crease or wrinkle marking the face, hand, or body; hence, a characteristic mark.
Lineament; feature; figure (of one's body).

text.text: A more-or-less straight sequence of people, objects, etc., either arranged as a queue or column and often waiting to be processed or dealt with, or arranged abreast of one another in a row (and contrasted with a column), as in a military formation. [from mid-16thc.]
examples: The line forms on the right.
There is a line of houses.

text: (military) The regular infantry of an army, as distinguished from militia, guards, volunteer corps, cavalry, artillery, etc.
A series or succession of ancestors or descendants of a given person; a family or race; compare lineage.
A small amount of text. Specifically:

text.text: A written or printed row of letters, words, numbers, or other text, especially a row of words extending across a page or column, or a blank in place of such text.
examples: The answer to the comprehension question can be found in the third line of the accompanying text.

text: A verse (in poetry).

text.text: A sentence of dialogue, especially [from the later 19thc.] in a play, movie, or the like.
examples: He was perfecting his pickup lines for use at the bar.
"It is what it is" was one his more annoying lines.

text.text: A lie or exaggeration, especially one told to gain another's approval or prevent losing it.
examples: Don't feed me a line!

text: Course of conduct, thought, occupation, or policy; method of argument; department of industry, trade, or intellectual activity. [from earlier 17thc.]

text.text: The official, stated position (or set of positions) of an individual or group, particularly a political or religious faction. [from later 19thc.]
examples: Remember, your answers must match the party line.

text.text: A set of products or services sold by a business, or by extension, the business itself. [from earlier 19thc.]
examples: line of business, product line
How many buses does the line have?
The airline is in danger of bankruptcy.

text: (stock exchange) A number of shares taken by a jobber.
A measure of length:
(historical) A tsarist-era Russian unit of measure, approximately equal to one tenth of an English inch, used especially when measuring the calibre of firearms.
One twelfth of an inch.
One fortieth of an inch.
(historical) A maxwell, a unit of magnetic flux.
(baseball, slang, 1800s, with "the") The batter’s box.
(fencing, ‘line of engagement’) The position in which the fencers hold their swords.

text.text: (engineering) Proper relative position or adjustment (of parts, not as to design or proportion, but with reference to smooth working).
examples: the engine is in line / out of line

text: A small portion or serving of a powdery illegal drug.
(obsolete) Instruction; doctrine.
(genetics) Population of cells derived from a single cell and containing the same genetic makeup.
(perfusion line) a set composed of a spike, a drip chamber, a clamp, a Y-injection site, a three-way stopcock and a catheter.
(ice hockey) A group of forwards that play together.

text.text: (medicine, colloquial) A vascular catheter.
examples: patient had a line inserted
line sepsis

text: #line (third-person singular simple present lines, present participle lining, simple past and past participle lined)

text.text: (transitive) To place (objects) into a line (usually used with "up"); to form into a line; to align.
examples: to line troops

text.text: (transitive) To place persons or things along the side of for security or defense; to strengthen by adding; to fortify.
examples: to line works with soldiers

text: (transitive) To form a line along.

text.text: (transitive) To mark with a line or lines, to cover with lines.
examples: to line a copy book

text: (transitive, obsolete) To represent by lines; to delineate; to portray.

text.text: (transitive) To read or repeat line by line.
examples: to line out a hymn

text.text: (intransitive, baseball) To hit a line drive; to hit a line drive which is caught for an out. Compare fly and ground.
examples: Jones lined to left in his last at-bat.

text: (transitive) To track (wild bees) to their nest by following their line of flight.
(transitive) To measure.
#line (uncountable)
(obsolete) Flax; linen, particularly the longer fiber of flax.
#line (third-person singular simple present lines, present participle lining, simple past and past participle lined)

text.text: (transitive) To cover the inner surface of (something), originally especially with linen.
examples: The bird lines its nest with soft grass.
to line a cloak with silk or fur
to line a box with paper or tin
paintings lined the walls of the cavernous dining room

text: To reinforce (the back of a book) with glue and glued scrap material such as fabric or paper.

text.text: (transitive) To fill or supply (something), as a purse with money.
examples: to line the shelves

text: #line (third-person singular simple present lines, present participle lining, simple past and past participle lined)
(transitive, now rare, of a dog) To copulate with, to impregnate.
#catch (countable and uncountable, plural catches)

text.text: (countable) The act of seizing or capturing.
examples: The catch of the perpetrator was the product of a year of police work.

text.text: (countable) The act of catching an object in motion, especially a ball.
examples: The player made an impressive catch.
Nice catch!

text.text: (countable) The act of noticing, understanding or hearing.
examples: Good catch. I never would have remembered that.

text.text: (uncountable) The game of catching a ball.
examples: The kids love to play catch.

text.text: (countable) Something which is captured or caught.
examples: The fishermen took pictures of their catch.
The catch amounted to five tons of swordfish.

text.text: (countable, colloquial, by extension) A find, in particular a boyfriend or girlfriend or prospective spouse.
examples: Did you see his latest catch?
He's a good catch.

text.text: (countable) A stopping mechanism, especially a clasp which stops something from opening.
examples: She installed a sturdy catch to keep her cabinets closed tight.

text.text: (countable) A hesitation in voice, caused by strong emotion.
examples: There was a catch in his voice when he spoke his father's name.

text.text: (countable, sometimes  noun adjunct) A concealed difficulty, especially in a deal or negotiation.
examples: It sounds like a great idea, but what's the catch?
Be careful, that's a catch question.

text.text: (countable) A crick; a sudden muscle pain during unaccustomed positioning when the muscle is in use.
examples: I bent over to see under the table and got a catch in my side.

text: (countable) A fragment of music or poetry.
(obsolete) A state of readiness to capture or seize; an ambush.
(countable, agriculture) A crop which has germinated and begun to grow.
(obsolete) A type of strong boat, usually having two masts; a ketch.
(countable, music) A type of humorous round in which the voices gradually catch up with one another; usually sung by men and often having bawdy lyrics.
(countable, music) The refrain; a line or lines of a song which are repeated from verse to verse.
(countable, cricket, baseball) The act of catching a hit ball before it reaches the ground, resulting in an out.
(countable, cricket) A player in respect of his catching ability; particularly one who catches well.
(countable, rowing) The first contact of an oar with the water.
(countable, phonetics) A stoppage of breath, resembling a slight cough.
Passing opportunities seized; snatches.
A slight remembrance; a trace.
#catch (third-person singular simple present catches, present participle catching, simple past and past participle caught)
(heading) To capture, overtake.

text.text: (transitive) To capture or snare (someone or something which would rather escape). [from 13thc.]
examples: I hope I catch a fish.  He ran but we caught him at the exit.  The police caught the robber at a nearby casino.

text: (transitive) To entrap or trip up a person; to deceive. [from 14thc.]
(transitive, figurative, dated) To marry or enter into a similar relationship with.

text.text: (transitive) To reach (someone) with a strike, blow, weapon etc. [from 16thc.]
examples: If he catches you on the chin, you'll be on the mat.

text.text: (transitive) To overtake or catch up to; to be in time for. [from 17thc.]
examples: If you leave now you might catch him.  I would love to have dinner but I have to catch a plane.

text.text: (transitive) To unpleasantly discover unexpectedly; to unpleasantly surprise (someone doing something). [from 17thc.]
examples: He was caught on video robbing the bank.  He was caught in the act of stealing a biscuit.

text.text: (transitive) To travel by means of. [from 19thc.]
examples: catch the bus

text: (transitive, rare) To become pregnant. (Only in past tense or as participle.) [from 19thc.]
(heading) To seize hold of.

text.text: (transitive, dated) To grab, seize, take hold of. [from 13thc.]
examples: I caught her by the arm and turned her to face me.

text.text: (transitive) To take or replenish something necessary, such as breath or sleep. [from 14thc.]
examples: I have to stop for a moment and catch my breath.  I caught some Z's on the train.

text.text: (transitive) To grip or entangle. [from 17thc.]
examples: My leg was caught in a tree-root.

text.text: (intransitive) To be held back or impeded.
examples: Be careful your dress doesn't catch on that knob.  His voice caught when he came to his father's name.

text.text: (intransitive) To engage with some mechanism; to stick, to succeed in interacting with something or initiating some process.
examples: Push it in until it catches.  The engine finally caught and roared to life.

text.text: (transitive) To have something be held back or impeded.
examples: I caught my heel on the threshold.

text.text: (intransitive) To make a grasping or snatching motion (at). [from 17thc.]
examples: He caught at the railing as he fell.

text.text: (transitive) Of fire, to spread or be conveyed to. [from 18thc.]
examples: The fire spread slowly until it caught the eaves of the barn.

text: (transitive, rowing) To grip (the water) with one's oars at the beginning of the stroke. [from 19thc.]

text.text: (intransitive, agriculture) To germinate and set down roots. [from 19thc.]
examples: The seeds caught and grew.

text: (transitive, surfing) To contact a wave in such a way that one can ride it back to shore.

text.text: (transitive, computing) To handle an exception. [from 20thc.]
examples: When the program catches an exception, this is recorded in the log file.

text: (heading) To intercept.

text.text: (transitive) To seize or intercept an object moving through the air (or, sometimes, some other medium). [from 16thc.]
examples: I will throw you the ball, and you catch it.  Watch me catch this raisin in my mouth.

text: (transitive, now rare) To seize (an opportunity) when it occurs. [from 16thc.]

text.text: (transitive, cricket) To end a player's innings by catching a hit ball before the first bounce. [from 18thc.]
examples: Townsend hit 29 before he was caught by Wilson.

text.text: (transitive, intransitive, baseball) To play (a specific period of time) as the catcher. [from 19thc.]
examples: He caught the last three innings.

text: (heading) To receive (by being in the way).

text.text: (transitive) To be the victim of (something unpleasant, painful etc.). [from 13thc.]
examples: You're going to catch a beating if they find out.

text.text: (transitive) To be touched or affected by (something) through exposure. [from 13thc.]
examples: The sunlight caught the leaves and the trees turned to gold.  Her hair was caught by the light breeze.

text.text: (transitive) To be infected by (an illness). [from 16thc.]
examples: Everyone seems to be catching the flu this week.

text: (intransitive) To spread by infection or similar means.

text.text: (transitive, intransitive) To receive or be affected by (wind, water, fire etc.). [from 18thc.]
examples: The bucket catches water from the downspout.  The trees caught quickly in the dry wind.

text.text: (transitive) To acquire, as though by infection; to take on through sympathy or infection. [from 16thc.]
examples: She finally caught the mood of the occasion.

text.text: (transitive) To be hit by something.
examples: He caught a bullet in the back of the head last year.

text: (intransitive) To serve well or poorly for catching, especially for catching fish.

text.text: (intransitive) To get pregnant.
examples: Well, if you didn't catch this time, we'll have more fun trying again until you do.

text: (heading) To take in with one's senses or intellect.

text.text: (transitive) To grasp mentally: perceive and understand. [from 16thc.]
examples: Did you catch his name?  Did you catch the way she looked at him?

text.text: (transitive, informal) To take in; to watch or listen to (an entertainment). [from 20thc.]
examples: I have some free time tonight so I think I'll catch a movie.

text.text: (transitive) To reproduce or echo a spirit or idea faithfully. [from 17thc.]
examples: You've really caught his determination in this sketch.

text: (heading) To seize attention, interest.
(transitive) To charm or entrance. [from 14thc.]

text.text: (transitive) To attract and hold (a faculty or organ of sense). [from 17thc.]
examples: He managed to catch her attention.  The enormous scarf did catch my eye.

text: (heading) To obtain or experience
#trip up (third-person singular simple present trips up, present participle tripping up, simple past and past participle tripped up)
(intransitive) To commit an error, make a mistake.
(transitive) To cause (someone) to commit an error, trick into a mistake.

(transitive) To cause (someone) to fall or stumble.
#error (countable and uncountable, plural errors)
(uncountable) The state, quality, or condition of being wrong.
(countable) A mistake; an accidental wrong action or a false statement not made deliberately.
(countable, uncountable) Sin; transgression.
(computing, countable) A failure to complete a task, usually involving a premature termination.
(statistics, countable) The difference between a measured or calculated value and a true one.
(baseball, countable) A play which is scored as having been made incorrectly.
(appellate  law, uncountable) One or more mistakes in a trial that could be grounds for review of the judgement.
Any alteration in the DNA chemical structure occurring during DNA replication, recombination or repairing.
#error (third-person singular simple present errors, present participle erroring, simple past and past participle errored)

text.text: (computing) To function improperly due to an error, especially accompanied by error message.
examples: The web-page took a long time to load and errored out.
Remove that line of code and the script should stop erroring there.
This directory errors with a "Permission denied" message.

text.text: (telecommunications) To show or contain an error or fault.
examples: The block transmission errored near the start and could not be received.

text: (nonstandard) To err.
#true (comparative truer or more true, superlative truest or most true)

text.text: (of a statement) Conforming to the actual state of reality or fact; factually correct.
examples: This is a true story.

text.text: Conforming to a rule or pattern; exact; accurate.
examples: a true copy;   a true likeness of the original

text.text: (logic) Of the state in Boolean logic that indicates an affirmative or positive result.
examples: "A and B" is true if and only if "A" is true and "B" is true.

text.text: Loyal, faithful.
examples: He’s turned out to be a true friend.

text.text: Genuine; legitimate.
examples: This is true Parmesan cheese.
The true king has returned!

text.text: Used in the designation of group of species, or sometimes a single species, to indicate that it belongs to the clade its common name (which may be more broadly scoped in common speech) is restricted to in technical speech, or to distinguish it from a similar species, the latter of which may be called false.
examples: true sparrows
true spiders
true blusher

text: (of an aim or missile in archery, shooting, golf, etc.) Accurate; following a path toward the target.

text.text: (Of a literary genre) based on actual historical events.
examples: true crimetrue romance

text: #true (not comparable)

examples: We spent all night truing up the report.

text.text: (intransitive) To move back and forth repeatedly and somewhat loosely.
examples: The flag waved in the gentle breeze.

text: (intransitive) To move one’s hand back and forth (generally above the head) in greeting or departure.

examples: I waved goodbye from across the room.

text: (intransitive) To have an undulating or wavy form.
(transitive) To raise into inequalities of surface; to give an undulating form or surface to.
(transitive) To produce waves to the hair.

examples: Jones waves at strike one.

text.text: (transitive) To cause to move back and forth repeatedly.
examples: The starter waved the flag to begin the race.

text.text: A moving disturbance in the level of a body of liquid; an undulation.
examples: The wave traveled from the center of the lake before breaking on the shore.

text: (poetic) The ocean.

text.text: (physics) A moving disturbance in the energy level of a field.
examples: Gravity waves, while predicted by theory for decades, have been notoriously difficult to detect.

text.text: A shape that alternatingly curves in opposite directions.
examples: Her hair had a nice wave to it.

text: Any of a number of species of moths in the geometrid subfamily Sterrhinae, which have wavy markings on the wings.

examples: He dismissed her with a wave of the hand.

text.text: (figurative) A sudden unusually large amount of something that is temporarily experienced.
examples: A wave of shoppers stampeded through the door when the store opened for its Christmas discount special.

examples: I've seen it happen a hundred times.

examples: We've received an interesting letter from a Mrs. Miggins of London.

text.text: Any, every; used before a noun which has become modified to limit its scope; also used with a negative to indicate not a single one.
examples: A man who dies intestate leaves his children troubles and difficulties.
He fell all that way, and hasn't a bump on his head?

text: Used before plural nouns modified by few, good many, couple, great many, etc.

text.text: Someone or something like; similar to; Used before a proper noun to create an example out of it.
